journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Thermal post-buckling of laminated and isotropic rectangular plates with fixed edges: Comparison of experimental and numerical results

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, McGill University, Canada
2Department of Mechanical Engineering, Iran University of Science and Technology, Iran

author-notes.corresp: Dr Marco Amabili, Department of Mechanical Engineering, McGill University, Macdonald Engineering Building, 817 Sherbrooke Street West, Montreal, PQ, Canada H3A 2K6. Email: marco.amabili@mcgill.ca

abstract.p: Post-buckling behaviors of laminated composite and isotropic rectangular plates subjected to various thermal changes are studied. Geometric imperfections are taken into account since they play a fundamental role. The plate is modeled using a nonlinear, higher order shear deformation theory. Plates with clamped edges are considered. A pseudo-arc length continuation method is used to obtain numerical results. Laboratory experiments have been performed in order to compare to the numerical calculations.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Plates can be subjected to significant thermal variations with respect to the assembly temperature. This may introduce very large thermal stresses in plates with fixed edges. Thin plates with fixed edges may buckle due to small thermal variations. Gossard et al.1 investigated thermal buckling of plates. Singh et al.2 studied the thermal buckling and post-buckling behaviors of shear deformable laminated composite plates by employing a four-node rectangular C1 continuous finite element. Shi et al.3 investigated the post-buckling of symmetrically laminated, antisymmetric angle-ply, and deflection of unsymmetrically laminated composite plates under mechanical and thermal loads. The thermal post-buckling behaviors of graphite/epoxy multi-layered rectangular plates with various boundary conditions were studied by Singha et al.4 using the finite element method. Temperature-dependent thermal and elastic properties of the material were used in the analysis. Shukla and Nath5 presented the post-buckling analysis for shear deformable cross-ply laminated composite rectangular plates subjected to the combination of in-plane edge compressive mechanical loading and thermal loads due to a linearly varying temperature across the thickness. The formulation is based on the first-order shear deformation theory and von-Karman-type nonlinearity. The effects of temperature-dependent mechanical and thermal properties on the critical temperature and the post-buckling response were studied by Shukla et al.6 Ge et al.7 studied the thermomechanical post-buckling behavior of composite laminated plates using a first-order shear deformation theory with the aid of the B-spline finite strip method under the combination of temperature load and applied uni-axial mechanical stress.

Girish and Ramachandra8 investigated the post-buckling and the post-buckled linear (small-amplitude) vibrations of rectangular plates with initial geometric imperfections. Lee and Reddy9 analyzed the transient nonlinear response of laminated composite plates under thermomechanical loading. Ribeiro10 studied nonlinear vibrations of rectangular plates under thermal loads. Amabili and Carra11 investigated post-buckling and nonlinear forced vibrations of isotropic rectangular plates. Pandey et al.12 used a higher order shear deformation theory to study the post-buckling of plates under constant and linear temperature variations across the thickness. Exact solution for linear buckling of rectangular plates is presented by Hosseini-Hashemi et al.13

The literature reviewed above does not present experimental results for thermal post-buckling of plates. In this study, experiments are carried out for post-buckling of clamped rectangular isotropic and woven fabric composite plates under uniform temperature change. A numerical nonlinear model is developed based on higher order shear deformation theory in order to compare numerical and experimental results. Geometric imperfections are taken into account in the model since they always appear in the experiments.

sec.title: Numerical model
sec.p: A rectangular plate of uniform thickness h and in-plane dimensions a and b is assumed; the coordinate system (O; x, y, z) is introduced, where the origin O is assumed at a plate corner on the middle plane of the plate, x and y the in-plane coordinates, and z the out-of-plane coordinate. Five independent variables, three displacements u, v, w and two rotations ϕ1 and ϕ2, are used to describe the plate’s middle plane deformation; the geometric imperfection w0 in normal direction is also introduced. A nonlinear, third-order shear deformation theory of plates has been introduced by Reddy,14–16 while a consistent nonlinear third-order shear deformation theory of shells retaining in-plane nonlinear terms has been introduced by Amabili and Reddy.17 The displacements of a generic point of the plate are related to the middle plane displacements by (1)u1=u+zφ1+z2ψ1+z3γ1+z4θ1 (2)u2=v+zφ2+z2ψ2+z3γ2+z4θ2 (3)u3=w+w0 where ϕ1 and ϕ2 are the rotations of the transverse normals at z = 0 about the y and x axes, respectively, and the other terms can be computed as functions of w, ϕ1, and ϕ2. After satisfying the zero shear strains at z = ±h/2, the following expressions are obtained16 (4)u1=u+zφ1-43h2z3(φ1+∂w∂x) (5)u2=v+zφ2-43h2z3(φ2+∂w∂y) (6)u3=w+w0 where the geometric imperfection w0 in the normal direction has been introduced. Equations (4) and (5) represent the parabolic distribution of shear effects through the thickness and satisfy the zero shear boundary condition at both the top and bottom surfaces of the plate.

The strain–displacement equations, keeping terms up to z3, can be written as16 (7)ɛx=ɛx,0+z(kx (0)+z2kx (2)) (8)ɛy=ɛy,0+z(ky (0)+z2ky (2)) (9)γxy=γxy,0+z(kxy (0)+z2kxy (2)) (10)γxz=γxz,0+z2kxz (1) (11)γyz=γyz,0+z2kyz (1) where ɛx,0, ɛy,0, γxy,0, γxz,0, γyz,0, kx (0), ky (0), kx (2), ky (2), kxy (0), kxy (2), kxz (1), and kyz (1) are defined in Appendix 1.

The stress–strain relations for the kth orthotropic lamina of the plate, in the material principal coordinates, under the hypothesis σ3=0, are given by (12){σ1σ2τ23τ13τ12}(k)=[c11c12000c21c2200000G2300000G1300000G12](k) ({ɛ1ɛ2γ23γ13γ12}-{α1α2000}(k)ΔT0) where G12, G13, and G23 are the shear moduli in 1-2, 1-3, and 2-3 directions, respectively, and the coefficients cij are given in Appendix 1; τ13 and τ23 are the shear stresses and the superscript (k) the kth layer within a laminate; α1 and α2 are the coefficients of thermal expansion in 1 and 2 directions of the kth layer, respectively, and ΔT0 (K) is the temperature variation (assumed to be uniform along the plate) with respect to a reference temperature. Equation (12) is obtained (1) under the transverse isotropy assumption with respect to planes parallel to the 2-3 plane, i.e. assuming fibers in the direction parallel to axis 1, so that E2 = E3, G12 = G13 and ν12 = ν13, and (2) solving the constitutive equations for ε3 as function of ε1 and ε2 and then eliminating it.

Equation (14) can be transformed to the plate coordinates (x, y, z) by the following vectorial equation (13){σxσyτyzτxzτxy}(k)=[Q](k){ɛx,0ɛy,0γyz,0γxz,0γxy,0}+z[Q](k){kx (0)ky (0)00kxy (0)} +z2[Q](k){00kyz (1)kxz (1)0}+z3[Q](k){kx (2)ky (2)00kxy (2)} -ΔT0[T1 -1C](k){α1α2000}(k) where [Q](k) is the 5 × 5 matrix of the material properties of the kth layer transformed in the plate principal coordinates and it is given in Appendix 2, as well as the transformation matrix T1.

The elastic strain energy UP of the plate is given by (14)UP=12∑k=1 K∫0 a∫0 b∫h(k-1) h(k) [σx (k)(ɛx-ΔT0αx (k)) +σy (k)(ɛy-ΔT0αy (k))+τxy (k)(γxy-ΔT0αxy (k)) +τxz (k)γxz+τyz (k)γyz ]dxdydz, where K is the total number of layers in the laminated shell, a and b the in-plane dimensions, and (h(k−1), h(k)) the z coordinates of the kth layer. In equation (14), the transformed coefficients of thermal expansion αx (k), αy (k) and αxy (k) are given by (15){αxαy00αxy}(k)=[T2](k)-1{α1α2000}(k)=[T1](k)T{α1α2000}(k)
By using the notation introduced in equation (15), the last term in equation (13) can be rewritten as (16)-ΔT0[Q](k){αxαy00αxy}(k)
The boundary conditions for clamped plates are (17)u=v=w=φ1=φ2=0,atx=0,a,and>aty=0,b

An expansion of plate displacements and rotations is used to discretize the system (18)u(x,y,t)=∑m=1 M∑n=1 Nu2m,n(t)sin(2mπx/a)sin(nπy/b) (19)v(x,y,t)=∑m=1 M∑n=1 Nvm,2n(t)sin(mπx/a)sin(2nπy/b) (20)w(x,y,t)=∑m=1 M∧∑n=1 N∧wm,n(t)sin(mπx/a)sin(nπy/b) (21)φ1(x,y,t)=∑m=1 M∧∑n=1 N∧φ12m,n(t)sin(2mπx/a)sin(nπy/b) (22)φ2(x,y,t)=∑m=1 M∧∑n=1 N∧φ2m,2n(t)sin(mπx/a)sin(2nπy/b) where m and n are the numbers of half-waves in x and y directions, respectively, t the time, and um,n(t), vm,n(t), wm,n(t), φ1m,n(t), and φ2m,n(t) the generalized coordinates, which are unknown functions of t. M and N indicate the terms necessary in the expansion of the in-plane displacements and, in general, are larger than M∧ and N∧, respectively, which indicate the terms in the expansion of out-of-plane displacement and rotations. The set of expansions in equations (18) to (22) has shown good convergence in previous studies by Amabili for vibrations of plates with the same boundary conditions. However, a different set of functions can be used.

Initial geometric imperfections of the rectangular plate associated to zero initial stress are considered only in z direction. The imperfection w0 is expanded in the same form of w, i.e. in a double Fourier sine series satisfying the boundary conditions at the plate edges (23)w0(x,y)=∑m=1 M~∑n=1 N~Am,nsin(mπx/a)sin(nπy/b) where Am,n is the modal amplitude of imperfections and N~ and M~ the integers indicating the number of terms in the expansion.
The following notation is introduced for brevity (24)q={um,n,vm,n,wm,n,φ1m,n,φ2m,n}T,m=1,…,MorM∧ and n=1,…,NorN∧
The generic element of the time-dependent vector q is referred to as qj; the dimension of q is N¯, which is the number of degrees of freedom (DOF) used in the mode expansion.
The generalized forces Qj are obtained by differentiation of the virtual work done by external forces (25)Qj=∂W∂qj,forj=1,…N¯
In the present case, no external forces are applied to the plate, so Qj = 0.
The nonlinear equilibrium equations are (26)∂UP∂qj=Qj,j=1,…N¯

The differentiation of the maximum potential energy of the plate gives quadratic and cubic nonlinearities (27)∂Up∂qj=∑i=1 N¯fj,iqi+∑i,k=1 N¯fj,i,kqiqk +∑i,k,l=1 N¯fj,i,k,lqiqkql,j=1,…N¯ where the coefficients f have long expressions that include also geometric imperfections. In particular, quadratic terms appear in all the equations of motion as a consequence of including in-plane generalized coordinates and geometric imperfections.

sec.title: Laboratory experiments
sec.p:
Experiments were conducted on four plates having the same in-plane free dimension a = b = 0.25 m bolted to a steel frame having coefficient of thermal expansion αf = 11.6 × 10−6 K−1. The boundary conditions approximate those of a clamped plate, as shown in Figure 1, since the plate is bolted to a solid frame. The plates, once bolted to the frame, presented geometric deviations with respect those of a perfectly flat plate due to manufacturing imperfections (mostly of the frame) and bolting. Two of the tested plate are made of 304 stainless steel, with material properties: E = 193 × 109 Pa, ρ = 8000 kg/m3, ν = 0.29 and αp = 17.2 × 10−6 K−1, with two different thicknesses: h = 0.5 and 0.8 mm. The effective coefficient of thermal expansion is given by the difference between the one of the plates and the one of the frames, therefore α = 5.6 × 10−6 K−1 is used in the calculation for the steel plates. The other two pates are made of graphite/epoxy woven fabric (3 k pan carbon fiber and 5052 epoxy resin) with material properties: E1 = E2 = 55 × 109Pa, G12 = 4.48 × 109Pa, G23 = 4.14 × 109Pa, ν12 = 0.04, ρ = 1500 kg/m3. The coefficient of thermal expansion of the composite plates is practically zero; so, the effective coefficient of thermal expansion considering the effect of the frame is negative α = −11.6 × 10−6 K−1. The two composite plates were made of four layers, with a global thickness h = 1 mm, and of six layers, with a global thickness h = 1.5 mm. Figure 1.
Woven fabric composite plate of 0.8 mm thickness assembled into the supporting steel frame during imperfection measurement.

The plate bolted to the frame (both at the same temperature at the time of assemblage) was placed in a thermal chamber for testing, and the temperature was slowly increased (for stainless steel plates) or decreased (for composite plates) and the plate deflection at the center was measured by an inductive proximity sensor that was calibrated and found to be linear for displacements up to 2.5 mm. Due to the geometric imperfections of the tested specimens, a continuous deformation was registered by varying the temperature. In order to use the inductive proximity sensor to measure deflection of the composite plate, a very thin aluminum foil was fixed at the center of the plate.

Geometric deviation from the ideal flat surface of the plates assembled to the frame has been measured by using a DEA coordinate measurement machine, as shown in Figure 1. The imperfection measurements for the 0.8-mm thick 304 stainless steel and for the 1.5-mm thick four-layer composite plate are given in Figure 2(a) to (c), respectively. The maximum deviation is about 1.5 mm for the stainless steel plate and 1 mm for the composite plate; the plates present a geometric imperfection with a shape similar to the one of the fundamental modes (1,1). Figure 2.
Measured deviation from the flat surface of the tested plates assembled into the supporting steel frame: (a) 0.8 mm thick stainless steel plate; (b) stainless steel plate 0.8 mm thick assembled flipping the plate of 180° about the x axis and (c) 1.5-mm thick woven fabric composite plate.

sec.title: Numerical simulations
sec.p: The nonlinear equilibrium equations (14) have been obtained using the Mathematica computer software.18 A non-dimensionalization of variables is also performed for computational convenience: the buckling amplitudes are divided by the plate thickness h. The resulting N¯ equations are studied using the software AUTO19 for continuation and bifurcation analysis of nonlinear ordinary differential equations. The software AUTO is capable of continuation of the solution, bifurcation analysis and branch switching using pseudo-arc length continuation16 and collocation methods. In the present case, the temperature variation is used as bifurcation variable. Pitchfork bifurcations are detected in case of perfect flat plates and the two resulting branches (post-buckling) have been followed. In case of plates with geometric imperfections, no pitchfork bifurcations are detected but there is a continuous increase of the plate deflection as a consequence of the temperature variation.

The calculations in this article are for thin plates. Therefore, the effect of shear deformation is negligible and the same results are obtained using the Von Kárman nonlinear plate theory modified to take into account laminated plates.20 If not differently specified, 39 DOF are used in the model built using the Von Kárman theory: w1,1, w3,1, w5,1, w7,1, w1,3, w3,3, w5,3, w7,3, w1,5, w3,5, w5,5, w1,7, w3,7, u2,1, u4,1, u6,1, u8,1, u2,3, u4,3, u6,3, u8,3, u2,5, u4,5, u6,5, u2,7, u4,7, v1,2, v3,2, v5,2, v7,2, v1,4, v3,4, v5,4, v7,4, v1,6, v3,6, v5,6, v1,8, v3,8. The analogous model that uses the nonlinear shear deformation theory requires 65 DOF, with additional 13 DOF for the expansion of ϕ1 and other 13 for ϕ2.

Initially, a numerical test has been performed in order to study the convergence of the buckling temperature parameter λT=1000αΔT0 for the square isotropic clamped plate under uniform temperature variation studied by Gossard et al.1 and by Liew et al.21 and having the following dimensions and material properties: a = b = 0.1 m, h = 0.001 m, E = 198 × 109 Pa, ρ = 7850 kg/m3, ν = 0.3, and α = 2 × 10−6 K−1. Results obtained using the Von Kárman theory are reported in Table 1 and show convergence of the present model to the results in literature. Table 1.
Convergence of the buckling temperature parameter λT=1000αΔT0 for the isotropic clamped plate studied by Gossard et al.1 and by Liew et al.21
39 DOF 63 DOF 107 DOF Gossard et al.1 Liew et al.21
0.375 0.36 0.34 0.337 0.333

sec.title: Comparison of numerical and experimental results
sec.p:
Figure 3 shows the effect of geometric imperfections with the shape of the fundamental mode (1,1), i.e. sin(πx/a)sin(πy/b), for different amplitudes A11 for the 304 stainless steel plate of thickness h = 0.5 mm. Except for the perfectly flat plate (A11 = 0), a continuous deflection of the plate without any bifurcation point is obtained by increasing the temperature. Experimental data (circles in Figure 3) are not far from the curve obtained for imperfection amplitude A11 = 2 h (maximum amplitude of deviation from the flat plate is 1 mm at the center), as shown in detail in Figure 4. The actual imperfection of the plate presents a shape more complicated than that the fundamental mode, but the introduction of this simple imperfection is able to capture the post-buckling behavior with sufficient accuracy. In Figures 3 and 4, results for the Von Kárman theory are plotted and they are practically coincident to those obtained by using the nonlinear third-order shear deformation theory for this case. Figure 3.
Numerical simulations for post-buckling displacement measured at the center of a 0.5-mm thick stainless steel (304) plate under the increase of temperature and effects of geometric imperfections. Experimental results for the same plate are indicated with circles. Figure 4.
Comparison of numerical simulation (continuous line) and experiments (circles) for post-buckling displacement measured at the center of a 0.5-mm thick stainless steel (304) plate under temperature increase. Initial geometric imperfection, A11 = 2 h.

Results for a slightly thicker 304 stainless steel plate with h = 0.8 mm are shown in Figure 5. In this case, calculations are presented for geometric imperfection A11 = 1.25 h, which is close to the experimentally measured geometric imperfection shown in Figure 2(a) and (b). This value of imperfection has been obtained by assuming that the imperfection is on the frame, and that therefore it is practically the same for all plates. In fact, the amplitude A11 = 1.25 h corresponds to a deviation of 1 mm at the center with respect to a flat plate, assuming the imperfection to be perfectly coincident with the fundamental mode (1,1), also close enough to the experimental measurement. Two sets of experiments are presented here. The set of experimental deflection with lower value is the original measurement, while the second set has been obtained after flipping the plate of 180° about the x axis; in this way, the plate is upside down. The fact that the plate buckle in the same direction indicates that mainly the imperfection is in the frame or is due to bolting, as shown by comparing the measured imperfections in the original test position, Figure 2(a), and flipping the plate of 180°, Figure 2(b). Figure 5.
Comparison of numerical simulation (continuous line) and experiments (circles) for post-buckling displacement measured at the center of a 0.8-mm thick stainless steel (304) plate under the increase of temperature. Initial geometric imperfection, A11 = 1.25 h. Two sets of experiments are reported, initially testing the plate (lower values) and then repeating the test with the plate assembled after 180° rotation around the x axis.

The post-buckling deflection of the woven fabric composite plate with h = 1 mm is shown in Figure 6. Calculations are made for geometric imperfection A11 = h, which again corresponds to a deviation of 1 mm with respect to the flat plate. As a consequence that the difference between the coefficient of thermal expansion of the plate and the one of the frame is negative, buckling of the plate is obtained by reducing the temperature. Instead, by increasing temperature, the plate is stretched and tends to recover is flat aspect reducing the geometric imperfections. The comparison of numerical and experimental results is really excellent in this case. Figure 6.
Comparison of numerical simulation (continuous line) and experiments (circles) for post-buckling displacement measured at the center of a four-layer 1-mm thick woven fabric composite plate decreasing temperature. Initial geometric imperfection, A11 = h.

Finally, Figure 7 shows the post-buckling of the woven fabric composite plate with h = 1.5 mm for geometric imperfection A11 = 0.67 h, which again corresponds to a deviation of 1 mm with respect to the flat plate, which is exactly the measured imperfection on the tested plate, as shown in Figure 2(c). The shape of the measured imperfection is similar to the one of the fundamental modes (1,1) of the plate. The comparison of numerical and experimental results is really excellent also in this case. Figure 7.
Comparison of numerical simulation (continuous line) and experiments (circles) for post-buckling displacement measured at the center of a six-layer 1.5-mm thick woven fabric composite plate decreasing temperature. Initial geometric imperfection, A11 = 0.67 h.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Experimental results for thermal post-buckling of stainless steel and graphite/epoxy woven fabric composite plates with fixed edges have been satisfactorily compared to numerical simulations. Geometric imperfections play a fundamental role, giving a continuous deflection versus temperature variation without the pitchfork bifurcation. The buckling is due to the different coefficients of thermal expansion of the plate and the frame: for stainless steel plate, the buckling is obtained by increasing the temperature, while for the composite plate it is obtained by reducing it.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: The first author acknowledges the financial support of the NSERC Discovery Grant, Canada Research Chair and Canada Foundation for Innovation programs of Canada and the PSR-SIIRI program of Québec.

sec.title: Stress–strain relations for a layer within a laminate
sec.p: The coefficients in equation (12) for a lamina are given by (41)c11=E11-ν12ν21,c12=c21=E2ν121-ν12ν21,c22=E21-ν12ν21,νijEj=νjiEi
It can be shown that (46)(T1 -1)T=T2

Therefore, the matrix [Q](k) in equation (13) is given by (47)[Q](k)=[T1 -1CT2](k)=[T2 TCT2](k) where C is the 5 × 5 matrix of coefficients cij in equations (12) and (41). As a consequence of the discontinuous variation of the stiffness matrix [Q](k) from layer to layer, the stresses may be discontinuous layer to layer.
